event.title: "No Shelter" Art Exhibit: Scott Wright
event.shortdesc: An exhibition of recent paintings, photographs and works on paper by Scott Wright.

fulldesc.p: Description: No Shelter, an exhibition of recent paintings, photographs and works on paper by Lancaster-based artist Scott Wright, will be on display in Ganser Gallery, located in Ganser Library from January 18 until March 3, 2011. On Thursday, March 3, from 5-7 p.m., the Gallery will host a talk by the artist, folled by a reception.

Artist Biography: Wright has exhibited widely at gallery and museum shows including the Butler Institute of American Art, Pennsylvania's Art of the State, the Woodmere Art Museum in Philadelphia, Mulligan Shanofsky Gallery in San Francisco and the University of Edinborough in Scotland. His artwork has been featured in articles in The New York Times and the Philadelphia Inquirer.

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of the Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday through Thursday, 12 - 4 p.m. and 7 - 9 p.m.; Friday, 12 - 4 p.m.; Sunday, 1 - 4 p.m. All Ganser Gallery Events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-871-2186, or by email, at tclever@millersville.edu

event.title: Film Screening: BOMBER
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Library presents an international film screening of "Bomber"

fulldesc.p: Millersville University Library presents an international film screening of "Bomber," Wednesday, February 9 at 7 p.m. This event will take place in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

Synopsis: BOMBER, a film by Paul Cotter. Alistar and Valerie have been planning a special trip to Germany for a very long time. When their son Ross stops by the house to send them off, happenstance turns into an impromptu family road trip of the most tortuous kind. Alistar berates Ross for all that he is not in life, while Valerie tries to keep the peace. It is soon discovered that Alistar's reason for the often comic, sometimes painful trip is to shed a guilt he's been carrying for years. Ultimately, the family learns they need each other more then they imagined. Premiered at the SXSW (South by Southwest) Film Festival where it played in competition and was nominated for the Grand Jury Prize.

Be sure to stick around for a second screening at 9 p.m. of the international film "The Wind Journeys."
This event, which is free and open to the public, is presented by the Millersville University Library and co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club.

event.title: Film Screening: The Wind Journeys
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Library presents a screening of the international film "The Wind Journeys"

fulldesc.p:
Millersville University Library presents a screening of the international film "The Wind Journeys," Wednesday, February 9 at 9 p.m. This event will take place in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.
Synopsis: THE WIND JOURNEYS, a film by Ciro Guerra. For most of his life, Ignacio Carrillo traveled the villages of northern Colombia, playing traditional songs on his accordion, a legendary instrument said to have once belonged to the devil. He eventually married and settled in a small town, leaving the nomadic life behind. But after the traumatic death of his wife, he vows to never play the accursed accordion again, and embarks on one last journey to return the instrument to its rightful owner. On the way, Ignacio is followed by Fermín, a spirited teenager determined to become his apprentice. Tired of loneliness, Ignacio accepts the young man as his pupil and together they traverse the vast Colombian terrain, discovering the musical diversity of Caribbean culture. Hardened by a life of solitude, Ignacio tries to discourage Fermín from following in his footsteps, but destiny has different plans for them. Colombia / 2009 / Drama / In Spanish with English subtitles.

Come early for a 7 p.m. screening of the international film "Bomber."
This event, which is free and open to the public, is presented by the Millersville University Library and co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club.

event.title: Ville After Dark: Simone
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark presents Simone, who will conduct a lecture interspersed with musical performances of her music.

fulldesc.p: Bio: Simone is her own woman, a singer, songwriter and performer whose ability to transcend genres echoes the tradition of her mother, musical icon and pioneer Nina Simone. Blessed with a rich vocal range, an innate skill for lyrical interpretation and a soul-deep understanding of music as a means of healing, empowerment and celebration, Simone is very much her mother's (Nina Simone) daughter, she is most assuredly a multi-talented artist in her own right.

This lecture will help the University community connect on a greater level with the film being shown the next evening. Having someone connected to the movie will allow audience members a glimpse at the inner workings of the film.
The February 26th event will be the presentation of the film For Colored Girls.
The February 28th event will be a panel of campus members discussing the impact of the movie and orignal play on our culture.

event.title: Regional Economics Challenge
event.shortdesc: Millersville University will host the Pennsylvania Southeast Regional Economics Challenge for the third time in four years.

fulldesc.p: This national competition features teams of high school students competing against one another on their knowledge of microeconomics, macroeconomics, international economics and current economic events. Students answer written questions both individually and as a team. The final round of competition features the top teams in each division facing off in a fast-paced economics quiz bowl.
Regional teams competing at Millersville University will be vying to advance to the state finals in Harrisburg and then on to a spot in the National Economics Challenge in New York City.

At Millersville University, the Center for Economic Education sponsors the Economics Challenge under the direction of Dr. Mike Gumpper, professor of economics. Gumpper will serve as emcee and judge for the competition that will involve approximately 140 regional high school students competing on 35 teams from York Suburban High School, Souderton Area Senior High School, Northern High School, Conestoga High School, Penn Manor High School and Red Land High School.

event.title: The American Institute of Graphic Arts Annual 50 Books/50 Covers Exhibition
event.shortdesc: Ganser Gallery at Millersville University PA will host The American Institute of Graphic Arts Annual 50 Books/50 Covers exhibition, April 1 â€“ May 5, 2011.

fulldesc.p: About AIGA 50 Books/50 Covers: For over 90 years, the 50/50 competition has aimed to identify the best-designed books and book covers that have been designed, produced and used in the marketplace, as chosen by distinguished jurors. As such, they become part of the AIGA Design Archives, a searchable visual database of exemplary design, as well as exhibited at the AIGA National Design Center in New York and offered as a traveling exhibition for display across the country. The physical artifacts are maintained at the AIGA Design Archives at the Denver Art Museum. A second set of the awarded books and covers becomes part of the Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Columbia University, New York.

This show features designs completed between January 1 and December 31, 2008, and was chosen by the following panel of judges:Jane Brown, Distributed Art Publishers (D.A.P.), Los Angeles; Rodrigo Corral,
Rodrigo Corral Design, New York; Vanessa Eckstein, Bløk Design, Mexico City; Franc Nunoo-Quarcoo (chair), University of Maryland, Baltimore County, Baltimore; Brett Yasko, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Notable designers such as Michael Bierut, Chipp Kidd, Paul Sahre, and Barbara deWilde are featured in this exhibition.

About AIGA: The American Institute of Graphic Arts, the professional association for design, is the premier place for design-to discover it, discuss it, understand it, appreciate it, be inspired by it.

AIGA's mission is to advance designing as a professional craft, strategic tool and vital cultural force. AIGA stimulates thinking about design through journals, conferences, competitions and exhibitions; demonstrates the value of design to business, the public and government officials; and empowers the success of designers at each stage of their careers by providing invaluable educational and social resources.

Founded in 1914, AIGA remains the oldest and largest professional membership organization for design. AIGA now represents more than 22,000 design professionals, educators and students through national activities and local programs developed by 63 chapters and 240 student groups. AIGA is a nonprofit, 501(c)(3) educational institution.

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of the Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday - Thursday 12pm- 4:00 pm and 7:00 pm - 9:00 pm; Friday, 12:00 - 4:00 pm; Sunday, 1:00-4:00 pm.

event.shortdesc: An exhibition that tells the stories of more then 30 master artists - coming from every corner of Pennsylvania

fulldesc.p:
Description: Making It Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania is an exhibition that tells the stories of more then 30 master artists whose work can heal the sick, challenge social inequity, assist in meditation and help communitites both grieve and celebrate.
Coming from every corner of Pennsylvania, the art represents a wide array of traditions such as African dance, stone wall construction, Native American flutes, Pysanky eggs, contemporary blacksmith work, woodcarving and Vietnamese funerary portraits.

event.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service
event.shortdesc: Come participate in Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service - REGISTER BY DEC. 13

fulldesc.p: Description: Volunteer Central at Millersville University is hosting Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service, January 17. Students will meet in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall at 8 a.m. and then commute to various location.

The King Day of Service is "a day on and not a day off" which allows Millersville students and American citizens worldwide to transform Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s life and teachings into community service that helps solve social problems. That service may meet a tangible need, such as fixing up a school or senior center, or it may meet a need of the spirit, such as building a sense of community or mutual responsibility.
For more information, email Volunteer Central at Volunteer.Central@millersville.edu or visit Volunteer Central at the Bedford House.
Registration is required. REGISTER BY DECEMBER 13 by clicking on the following link: MLK Jr. Day of Service.

event.title: Applying the Ocean-Earth-Atmospheric Sciences
event.shortdesc: Millersville's Department of Earth Sciences presents "Applying the Ocean-Earth-Atmospheric Sciences: Operational Oceanography at the Naval Oceanographic Office" with James Rigney, Chief Scientist.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University Department of Earth Sciences Seminar Series
Applying the Ocean-Earth-Atmospheric Sciences: Operational Oceanography at the Naval Oceanographic Office
James Rigney, Chief Scientist
Naval Oceanographic Office
Stennis Space Center, MS
Wednesday, January 19, 2011 from 4:30 pm to 5:30 pm in Caputo Hall 210
The talk is free and open to the public

Mr. Rigney oversees the transition of new technologies and scientific applications from the research and development community. He provides scientific and technical leadership in the application of the ocean sciences to the Naval Oceanographic Office (NAVOCEANO) mission of operationally supporting Navy and other Department of Defense planning and operations.

NAVOCEANO applies science and technology to provide U.S. Navy planners and operators with knowledge of the marine environment and its impact on operations. An overview of the roles of oceanographers, marine geologists, meteorologists, and other scientists in supporting this mission will be given. A specific example, ocean prediction, will be explored in order to illustrate the interaction between various earth system disciplines. Global and regional numerical ocean models are run each day at NAVOCEANO in order to predict currents, temperature, salinity, and optics. Atmospheric forcing is a direct and critical input to these models, while atmospheric corrections are needed to obtain accurate satellite-derived sea surface temperatures and elevations. Bathymetry provides the crucial lower boundary condition. This presentation will describe the atmospheric inputs, the overall predictive system, and the emerging use of tightly coupled air-ocean modeling systems at NAVOCEANO. Finally, career opportunities for geoscientists at NAVOCEANO will be described.
For more information contact: Dr. Todd Sikora, Todd.Sikora@millersville.edu

event.title: CANCELED: Climate Change Ethics Lecture
event.shortdesc: CANCELED EVENT: Ethics:The Crucial Missing Element in the Climate Change Debate.

p.strong: THIS EVENT HAS BEEN CANCELED DUE TO INCLIMATE WEATHER.

fulldesc.p: The MU Department of Geography and Transition Lancaster presents, Climate Ethics: The Crucial Missing Element in the Climate Change Debate, January 26, from 6-8 p.m.
A Lecture by Dr. Donald A. Brown, The Pennsylvania State University
What is the crucial missing element in the U.S. debate about climate change? Ethics.

Climate change must be seen as raising several civilization-challenging ethical challenges for the human race, yet, for the most part, these ethical questions have gone unexamined in public discussions of climate change issues. Brown will argue that the failure to look at climate change as an ethical problem has practical consequences. Join Millersville University's Geography Department and Transition Lancaster for a lively lecture and discussion!

event.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration with Julian Bond
event.shortdesc: Help celebrate the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. with Julian Bond.

fulldesc.p: Description: Celebrate the legacy of Dr.Martin Luther King Jr. with Julian Bond.

Bio: Beginning with his pivotal role in the Civil Rights Movement, Julian Bond - an expert on diversity in the law - has been on the cutting edge of social change and leadership. Legendary as the first black U.S. vice presidential nominee and former Chairman of the NAACP, Bond continues to deliver a powerful message of equality, freedom and justice with a renewed sense of relevance.

A first-hand eyewitness to many watershed moments in the history of the Civil Rights Movement, Bond delivers powerful speeches on the centuries-long struggle of African-Americans for equality, diversity in the shaping of laws and civil rights moving into the future, as well as keynotes on African American's impact on music, national affairs and leadership.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public. No tickets required.

event.title: Mural Development with Michelle Angela Ortiz
event.shortdesc: Mural Development with Michelle Angela Ortiz

fulldesc.p: Description: Michelle Angela Ortiz, artist, arts educator and muralist will be Millersville's artist-in-residence during the spring 2011 semester.

Ortiz will collaborate with Millersville University art and sociology students, as well as members of the Latino community in Lancaster City for the Millersville University - Lancaster Community Mural Project, culminating in the creation of two murals.
The project kicks off February 3, at 3:30, where Ortiz will discuss mural development. An overview of the project will also be discussed.

Biography: Michelle Angela Ortiz was born and raised in South Philadelphia. Her household flourished with her Latin American and Caribbean cultures. Her work focuses on the importance of time and existence. Culture, spirituality, community and the sense of self are also strong elements in her work.

As a highly skilled muralist, Ortiz has designed and created more than 30 large scale public works nationally and internationally in Fiji, Mexico, Ecuador and Costa Rica. Ortiz has also exhibited her paintings and prints in numerous galleries such as: The Painted Bride, Fox Gallery & The Kelly Writer's House (University of Pennsylvania), Stedman Gallery (Rutgers University), Goldey Paley Gallery (Moore College), Lorenzo Homar Gallery (Taller Puertorriqueño), Art Forms Gallery. Also, Ortiz has various works in permanent and private collections in Philadelphia and abroad.
Sponsors: Dr. Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, the Society on Latino Affairs, the University Theme Committee and Millersville's Department of Art & Design.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Primer
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Primer

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: At night and on weekends, four men in a suburban garage have built a cottage industry of error-checking devices. But, they know that there is something more. There is some idea, some mechanism, some accidental side effect that is standing between them and a pure leap of innovation. And so, through trial and error they are building the device that is missing most. However, two of these men find the device and immediately realize that it is too valuable to market. The limit of their trust in each other is strained when they are faced with the question, If you always want what you can't have, what do you want when you can have anything?
Discussant: Rob Spicer, instructor, communication studies
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Residency: Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Theatre presents The American Place Theatre's Literature to Life stage presentation of Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl By Harriet Jacobs Performed by Cherita Armstrong Adapted and Directed by Wynn Handman.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University Theatre presents The American Place Theatre's Literature to Life stage presentation of Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl By Harriet Jacobs Performed by Cherita Armstrong Adapted and Directed by Wynn Handman.

This Literature to Life original, adapted in 2006 was commissioned by and premiered at The New York Historical Society. The show features fifty minutes of verbatim performance. The author is the protagonist in this solo piece which illuminates in shocking fashion the traumas of slavery, particularly for women and children. The stage adaptation culminates in Harriet Jacobs' powerful and moving experiences during the seven years she spent hiding in The Loophole, a crawl space in her grandmother's attic. Audiences, having absorbed the images without sets or props, only the truth of the author's evocative words, will emerge with a visceral experience that may become an enduring part of their understanding of the "peculiar institution", slavery. Surrounded by a pre & post show discussion audiences will explore themes including resilience and survival.

Performance: 7:00p.m., MU Student Memorial Center, Multi-purpose Room (Recommended Ages 13 and up)
15 minute pre-show interactive discussion, a one hour performance, followed by a 15 minute post-show discussion

Audiences, having absorbed the images without sets or props, only the truth of the author's evocative words, will emerge with a visceral experience that may become an enduring part of their understanding of the "peculiar institution", slavery. event.title: Humanities Film Series: Food, Inc.
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Food, Inc.

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: In Food, Inc., filmmaker Robert Kenner lifts the veil on our nation's food industry, exposing the highly mechanized underbelly that has been hidden from the American consumer with the consent of our government's regulatory agencies, USDA and FDA. Our nation's food supply is now controlled by a handful of corporations that often put profit ahead of consumer health, the livelihood of the American farmer, the safety of workers and our own environment.

We have bigger-breasted chickens, the perfect pork chop, insecticide-resistant soybean seeds, even tomatoes that won't go bad, but we also have new strains of e coli--the harmful bacteria that causes illness for an estimated 73,000 Americans annually. We are riddled with widespread obesity, particularly among children, and an epidemic level of diabetes among adults.
Discussant: Dr. Julie Lombardi, Associate Professor, and Dr. Adele Ruszak, Assistant Professor, Wellness and Sports Sciences
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences and the Department of Wellness and Sports Sciences.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: High school student Olive Penderghast (Emma Stone) finds herself the victim of her school's "rumor mill" when she lies to her best friend Rhiannon (Alyson Michalka) about a weekend tryst with a fictional college freshman. Word quickly spreads of Olive's promiscuity and, much to her surprise, she welcomes the attention. When she agrees to help out a bullied friend by pretending to sleep with him, her image rapidly degrades to a more lascivious state and her world begins to spin out of control. As she helps more and more of her classmates and her lies continue to escalate, Olive must find a way to save face before the school's religious fanatic Marianne (Amanda Bynes) gets her expelled and she loses a shot at attaining her own happiness.

event.title: Diversity Speaker: Donna Rose
event.shortdesc: Donna Rose is a speaker from Common Roads, a safe haven for members of the LGBTQ community. Come hear her speak about her own journey as well as be educated on many issues faced daily.

fulldesc.p: Donna Rose, born as David, knew that as a man, she was not fully able to express herself. Because of this, she began the transition to become Donna. She speaks world wide educating people on the issues based around the LGBTQ community. It is no secret that there are extreme negatives pushed upon individuals because of their lives. Donna strongly believes that the best way to end this violence and negativity is through education.
On Monday, February 14, 2011, Rose will be in the Ford Atrium from 11 a.m. - 1 p.m. There will be an informal discussion from 11 a.m. - 12 p.m. and from 12 - 1 p.m. will be her more formal talk.

Donna now works for Common Roads Center. This is a center that runs on donations in Lancaster. It is a safe haven for members of the LGBTQ community. A Valentine's bake sale will be held outside of the Atrium in order to raise money to keep the center running.

It is crucial to take the time to attend events such as these in order to educate ourselves about the world and people around us. You never know what situations and people you will be meeting in your life, therefore wouldn't you like to be able to learn as much as you can about all different cultures while you have the chance?

Rose is a nationally recognized speaker, educator and advocate on transgender and transsexual issues. She is active in the leadership of several national GLBT advocacy organizations, is the author of an award-winning memoir, is heavily involved in national corporate diversity efforts.
Sponsered by: Millersville's Social Work Organization Diversity Committee

event.title: Waiting for Superman
event.shortdesc: The School of Education presents "Waiting for Superman," a documentary which has provoked stirring conversations among the educational community and beyond.

fulldesc.p:
When disaster strikes in America, heroes rush in. When all seems lost, real-life supermen (and women) step up to save the day. But, what if, right now, there is a hidden catastrophe spreading quietly, insidiously through our nation's cities, towns, and communities and yet, WE have the power to stop it?
"Davis Guggenheim's new film, Waiting for Superman, is nothing less than a wake-up call to all Americans. It is both a searing indictment of our education system and a desperate call-to-action to save our struggling schools." The Huffington Post
Panel Discussion immediately following the movie

Features:
Panel Moderator: Dr. Cheryl Desmond, Professor, Educational Foundations
Mr. Pedro Rivera, Superintendent, School District of Lancaster
Ms. Maureen Vogel, Social Studies Teacher, Reynolds Middle School
Mr. Mike Ronan, President of Lancaster / Lebanon PSEA
Ms. Marsha Fabian, NEA Director for PA
Ms. Lena Cordero, MU Elementary Education Program Graduate, Color of Teaching Mentor
Ms. Marianna Torres, High School Student, Color of Teaching Mentee

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Einstein Revealed
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Einstein Revealed

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: This two-hour program chronicles Albert Einstein's life and scientific achievements from his birth in 1879 to his death in 1955. Graphics depict some of Einstein's famous thought experiments including his eventual understanding of the interplay between the speed of light and time and his development of the special theory of relativity. The program also goes into depth about Einstein's personal life, including his romance with and marriage to fellow student Mileva Maric and the death of his father.

Einstein addresses gravitation in the universe with his general theory of relativity. This is confirmed experimentally in 1919 when a solar eclipse reveals stars in positions that could best be explained by his theory: that gravity causes light to bend.
Discussant: Dr. Mike Nolan, professor of physics
Sponsor: The University Theme Committee, the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences and the Department of Physics.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. event.title: Ville After Dark: Burlesque
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie: Burlesque

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: The Burlesque Lounge has its best days behind it. Tess, a retired dancer and owner of the venue, struggles to keep the aging theater alive, facing all kinds of financial and artistic challenges. With the Lounge's troupe members becoming increasingly distracted by personal problems and a threat coming from a wealthy businessman's quest to buy the spot from Tess, the good fortune seems to have abandoned the club altogether. Meanwhile, the life of Ali, a small-town girl from Iowa, is about to change dramatically. Hired by Tess as a waitress at the Lounge, Ali escapes a hollow past and quickly falls in love with the art of burlesque. Backed by newfound friends amongst the theater's crew, she manages to fulfill her dreams of being on stage herself. Things take a dramatic turn though when Ali's big voice makes her become the main attraction of the revue.
This movie will be shown at 9:30 p.m. and 12 a.m.
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Student Entrepreneur Conference
event.shortdesc: Students: Learn how to become an entrepreneur with Randal Pinkett, Ph.D, season 4 winner of "The Apprentice."

fulldesc.p: Description: Students looking to start their own businesses have a great opportunity this spring. Millersville University will host the 2011 Student Entrepreneur Conference, February 22, from 4-8 p.m., with special guest speaker Randal Pinkett, Ph.D., fourth season winner of the popular TV show, "The Apprentice."

Biography: Pinkett is the founder, chairman and CEO of BCT Partners in Newark, N.J., a consulting firm that he started during his undergraduate years at Rutgers University. Pinkett holds five degrees including a master's degree from the University of Oxford in England and a Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute for Technology.

Pinkett's book, "Campus CEO," is a guide for students on starting their own multi-million dollar businesses, during or after college. He also hosts the Campus CEO Challenge, a contest for high school and college students who wish to start their own businesses. The winners receive money to startup their business, as well as a consultation with Pinkett.
This year's conference will include breakout sessions exploring internships, networking and taking advantage of opportunities.

p.strong: The conference, which will be held on campus, in the Lehr Room, Gordinier Hall, is free and open to students. Registration is required; the first fifty students that register will receive a copy of Pinkett's book, "Campus CEO."

fulldesc.p: Contact: For more information or to register, contact Lori Leaman, assistant to executive director, civic & community engagement & research, by phone, at 717-872-3049, or by email, at Lori.Leaman@millersville.edu.

event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Blow-Up

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: Receiving Oscar nominations for its screenplay and direction, Antonioni's Blow-Up was "the highest-grossing art film to date," during its run in 1967 (Ebert) and hailed as "the movie of the year" by Village Voice film critic Andrew Sarris. Set in the swinging '60s in London, the film focuses on a mod fashion photographer (David Hemmings) whose life changes when he realizes he accidentally may have taken a photograph of a murder.
Discussant: Dr. Jen Miller, assistant professor of philosophy

event.title: Ville After Dark: For Colored Girls
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark presents "For Colored Girls" by Tyler Perry will be shown in Myers Auditorium at 9:30 p.m. and Midnight.

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: The movie is based on Ntozake Shange's play "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf." Unlike the original play which featured only 7 women known by colors performing the collection of 20 poems, the movie has given each of the 20 characters names. Each of the poems deal with intense issues that particularly impact women in a thought-provoking commentary on what it means to be a female of color in the world.
The movie will be shown Saturday evening at 9:30 p.m. and 12 a.m. in Myers Auditorium.
The film is being shown as part of the spring movie roster for Ville After Dark.

It is part of a three-day program around the movie. The February 25th event will be a lecture with Simone. Simone, the daughter of Nina Simone, is featured on the soundtrack for the film. The February 26th event will be the presentation of the film For Colored Girls. The February 28th event will be a panel of campus members discussing the impact of the movie and orignal play on our culture.

event.title: Artist Talk & Reception: Scott Wright
event.shortdesc: Artist talk and reception featuring Lancaster-based artist Scott Wright

fulldesc.p: Description: On Thursday, March 3, from 5-7 p.m., Ganser Gallery will host a talk featuring Lancaster-based artist Scott Wright, followed by a reception. No Shelter, an exhibition of recent paintings, photographs and works on paper by Wright, will be on display in Ganser Gallery, located in Ganser Library from Jan. 18 until March 3, 2011.

Artist Biography: Wright has exhibited widely at gallery and museum shows including the Butler Institute of American Art, Pennsylvania's Art of the State, the Woodmere Art Museum in Philadelphia, Mulligan Shanofsky Gallery in San Francisco and the University of Edinborough in Scotland. His artwork has been featured in articles in The New York Times and the Philadelphia Inquirer.

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of the Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday through Thursday, 12 - 4 p.m. and 7 - 9 p.m.; Friday, 12 - 4 p.m.; Sunday, 1 - 4 p.m. All Ganser Gallery Events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-871-2186, or by email, at Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu.

event.title: Anna Funk Lockey Lecture: Rachel Simmons

fulldesc.p: Rachel Simmons will give this year's Anna Funk Lockey lecture. Her topic, "Online Confidential: What Girls Do Online, Why They Do It and How To Parent Through It."
She will be available for book signing following the presentation.

Simmons is the author of the New York Times bestsellers Odd Girl Out: The Hidden Culture of Aggression in Girls and The Curse of the Good Girl: Raising Authentic Girls with Courage and Confidence. As an educator and coach, she works internationally to develop strategies to address bullying and empower girls.

Biography: Piscatello is founder and principal of Piscatello Design Centre. He is responsible for leading a team of graphic designers that create globally integrated brand identity systems, environmental graphics and interactive media for clients and cities around the world.

Piscatello was formerly a project director at Vignelli Associates where he collaborated with several international clients including the American Center in Paris, American Academy in Rome, Benetton, Guggenheim Museum, Frank Gehry and Partners, Richard Meier and Partners, Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Sea Containers and Warner Bros.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Mr. Nobody
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Mr. Nobody

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: Mr. Nobody explores the memories of a 120-year-old man whose choices as a child change his potential futures as an adult (Jared Leto). Starting in 2092, this imaginative and philosophical film explores the effect of choices on potential futures. Artsy and creative, the film slides between three possible life experiences using an innovative editing structure to engage spectators in the construction of the stories--essentially, the viewers mix the film into meaning (or not).
Discussant: Dr. Jill Craven, associate professor of film studies and Members of the Cine Club.
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Day of Percussion Concert - Day 1
event.shortdesc: Millersville University's music department presents a day of percussion concert

fulldesc.p: Description: The Department of Music at Millersville University and the Pennsylvania Chapter of the Percussive Arts Society are co-sponsoring, a Day of Percussion, March 18-19 at Millersville University - Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster.
The event begins Friday, March 18 at 7:30 p.m., with a concert featuring two internationally recognized percussion duos, Marassa and Loop 243.

Registration for clinics and sessions takes place Saturday, March 19, 9:30-10 a.m., followed by morning educational sessions on Brasilian music with Jorge Sacramento and marimba with Nick Papador. Following will be a special marching percussion presentation by the Capitol Drum Line. A festival of regional percussion ensembles takes place in Steinman Hall from 1-3:30 p.m., featuring percussion ensembles from Millersville University, Juniata College, Lancaster Catholic High School, Mannheim Township High School, Ephrata High School and the Pennsylvania Academy of Music. Internationally renowned drum set artist Billy Ward will present in Steinman Hall from 4-5:30 p.m.

The event concludes Saturday evening with a 7:30 p.m. Gala Concert, featuring Jorge Sacramento, Nicholas Papador, Overdekte Brug Percussie Trio and Billy Ward, with an all star ensemble of percussionists who had performed throughout the weekend.

A wide variety of music cultures will be represented at this event including traditional concert music, world music, mallet percussion, jazz and contemporary classical music. Cultures of Afro-Caribbean and West African folkloric background Haitian Vodou tradition, North American popular music contemporary classical music and Far Eastern traditions will be showcased.

The opportunity for students and faculty to mature in their interdisciplinary and multicultural understandings is almost self-evident in the experience of World Music and American musical cross-overs.

Ticket are required for this event. Tickets cost $10 general admission, $2 for registered participants in the workshop and may be purchased at the Ticket Office in the SMC, room 103, calling 717-872-3811, going online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com and at Millersville University - Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St.

event.location: Millersville University - Lancaster, 42 North Prince St., Lancaster

event.title: Rescheduled for 4/11 - Lecture: Hill Harper
event.shortdesc: Rescheduled for 4/11 - Hill Harper, an actor on the hit drama series CSI: New York, will speak at Millersville.

em.strong: *The date of this event has been changed to April 11, 2011, at 7:30 p.m. in Pucillo Gymnasium.*

fulldesc.p: Description: Hill Harper, Esq., "Motivating Young Men to be the Architect of Their Life."

Biography: Harper has won legions of admirers for his soulful portrayal of "Dr. Sheldon Hawkes" on the hit drama series CSI: New York. A talented actor, Harper's passion for his craft is surpassed only by his dedication to inspire America's youth. A firm believer that identity is not defined by skin color or circumstance, the charismatic Harper encourages audiences to "take your biggest dream, and double it."

Harper's newest book, The Conversation, explores the nature of love across generations and the current state of male-female relations. It offers practical solutions on how to improve communication across gender and age.

Wanting to make a mark past his writing, Harper works to enable positive social change as a spokesman and volunteer for Big Brothers, Big Sisters. Today, he continues in his efforts to better America's social climate and guide our youth as a strong and articulate voice for hope, education, and commitment.
Sponsors: Dr. Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, Federick Douglass Celebration of Black Culture.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: University Theatre Presents:Heathen Valley
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: HEATHEN VALLEY, a drama about an unforgettable journey into "the valley that forgot God" by Romulus Linney

fulldesc.p: University Theatre Presents: HEATHEN VALLEY, An unforgettable journey into "the valley that forgot God."
A drama by Romulus Linney. Directed by Tony Elliot

Plot Summary: Set in the 1860s in a remote valley in the mountains of North Carolina, the action of the play centers on the desire of the Episcopal Bishop of North Carolina to bring the word of God to a community so removed and untamed that brothers marry sisters and the people live lives of brutal violence and grinding poverty. But trying to force strong willed people to accept organized religion is never a good idea.

In this play, which the Philadelphia Daily news called a "minor masterpiece," Romulus Linney creates characters who are at once sympathetic and horrifying, creating humanity and nobility in the most unlikely places and situations.
Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville University

p.em: Heathen Valley is presented by special arrangement with Dramatists Play Service, Inc., New York

event.title: Tangled
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie: Tangled

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: After receiving the healing powers from a magical flower, the baby Princess Rapunzel is kidnapped from the palace in the middle of the night by Mother Gothel. Mother Gothel knows that the flower's magical powers are now growing within the golden hair of Rapunzel, and to stay young, she must lock Rapunzel in her hidden tower. Rapunzel is now a teenager and her hair has grown to a length of 70-feet. The beautiful Rapunzel has been in the tower her entire life, and she is curious of the outside world. One day, the bandit Flynn Ryder scales the tower and is taken captive by Rapunzel. Rapunzel strikes a deal with the charming thief to act as her guide to travel to the place where the floating lights come from that she has seen every year on her birthday. Rapunzel is about to have the most exciting and magnificent journey of her life.
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Being There
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Being There

fulldesc.p:
Synopsis: Being There features the masterful Peter Sellers as a man of limited intellect, Chance, who has served as the gardener at a wealthy estate in D.C. for his entire life. After the death of the estate’s owner, Chance leaves the safe haven of his former television-dominated world and enters the so-called "real world" of the Washington politics. Although Chance only knows television and his garden, his lack of depth is mistaken for profundity by the Washington elite, and he is catapulted to fame.
This film explores issues of identity as well as media celebrity, reminiscent of Oscar Wilde's idea that "most people are other people. Their thoughts are someone else’s opinions, their lives a mimicry, their passions a quotation."
Discussant: Dr. Jen Miller, Assistant Professor of Philosophy
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

event.title: Hazel I Jackson Lecture with Walter Mosley
event.shortdesc: Walter Ellis Mosley presents this year's Hazel I Jackson Lecture

fulldesc.p: Description: Walter Ellis Mosley will present this year's Hazel I Jackson Lecture, March 22 at 7:30 p.m.

Biography: Mosley is a prominent American novelist, most widely recognized for his crime fiction. He has written a series of best-selling historical mysteries featuring the hard-boiled detective Easy Rawlins, a black private investigator and World War II veteran living in theWatts neighborhood of Los Angeles; they are perhaps his most popular works.

Mosley started writing at 34 and has written every day since, penning more than 33 books in a variety of categories including non-mystery fiction, afrofuturist science fiction and non-fiction politics. Mosley made publishing history in 1997 by foregoing an advance to give the manuscript of Gone Fishin' to a small, independent publisher, Black Classic Press in Baltimore, run by former Black Panther Paul Coates. Mosley's fame increased in 1992 when then-presidential candidate Bill Clinton, a fan of murder mysteries, named Mosley as one of his favorite authors.
Sponsors: This event is sponsored by the University Theme Committee, Dr. Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration and the Frederick Douglass Celebratioin of Black Culture.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Science Olympiad
event.shortdesc: The School of Science and Mathematics will host the 4th Annual Central PA Regional Science Olympiad Competition.

fulldesc.p:
The School of Science and Mathematics at Millersville University will host the 4th Annual Central PA Regional Science Olympiad Competition. The event will take place on Saturday, March 26th, 2011.
This is the 27th year of the Science Olympiad. This event features premiere science competitions in the nation, providing rigorous challenges to nearly 6,000 middle and high school teams in 50 states. Science Olympiad competitions consist of a series of 23 team events in each division (Division B is middle school; Division C is high school). Each year, a portion of the events are rotated to reflect the ever-changing nature of genetics, earth science, chemistry, anatomy, physics, geology, mechanical engineering and technology.

The Central PA Regional Science Olympiad Competition at MU consists of approximately 15 middle school and 25 high schools every year. Currently, we have 40 (14 middle/26 high) schools registered to participate. Each school brings 15 students who compete in several events throughout the day (approximately 600 students). The competitions take place in the following MU buildings: Caputo/Roddy Halls, McComsey Hall, and Pucillo Gymnasium.
Dr. Maria V. Schiza (Chemistry)-Site-Director & Dr. Mehmet Goksu (Physics)-Co-Director

event.title: University Theatre Presents:Heathen Valley
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: HEATHEN VALLEY, an unforgettable journey into "the valley that forgot God."

fulldesc.p: University Theatre Presents: HEATHEN VALLEY, an unforgettable journey into "the valley that forgot God."
A drama by Romulus Linne. Directed by Tony Elliot.

Plot Summary: Set in the 1860s in a remote valley in the mountains of North Carolina, the action of the play centers on the desire of the Episcopal Bishop of North Carolina to bring the word of God to a community so removed and untamed that brothers marry sisters and the people live lives of brutal violence and grinding poverty. But trying to force strong willed people to accept organized religion is never a good idea.

In this play, which the Philadelphia Daily news called a "minor masterpiece," Romulus Linney creates characters who are at once sympathetic and horrifying, creating humanity and nobility in the most unlikely places and situations.
Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville University

p.em: Heathen Valley is presented by special arrangement with Dramatists Play Service, Inc., New York

event.title: Ville After Dark: Tron Legacy
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie - Tron Legacy

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: Sam Flynn (Hedlund), a rebellious 27-year-old, is haunted by the mysterious disappearance of his father Kevin Flynn (Bridges), a man once known as the world's leading video-game developer. When Sam investigates a strange signal sent from the old Flynn's Arcade -- a signal that could only come from his father-- he finds himself pulled into a digital world where Kevin has been trapped for 20 years. With the help of the fearless warrior Quorra (Wilde), father and son embark on a life-or-death journey across a cyber universe -- a universe created by Kevin himself that has become far more advanced with vehicles, weapons, landscapes and a ruthless villain who will stop at nothing to prevent their escape.

Biography: Englar's musical training includes performances in master classes with world- renowned classical guitarists Christopher Parkening and Manuel Barrueco. She is a member of the Guitar Foundation of America. Englar teaches private lessons in the York (Pa.) area, directs the Guitar Ensemble at Millersville University and performs in ensembles and as a soloist in the York-Lancaster-Harrisburg area.

event.title: Lecture: Don Eberly
event.shortdesc: "Frontier Diplomacy: My Last 16 Months in Afghanistan" will be presented by Don Eberly on Monday, March 28th at 7 p.m. in Caputo 210.

fulldesc.p: Description: Don Eberly will be giving a speech titled, "Frontier Diplomacy: My Last 16 Months in Afghanistan," on Monday, March 28th at 7 p.m. in Caputo 210, about his experiences while over seas in Afghanistan.
Bio: Don Eberly is a former White House aide, leading author and expert on reconstruction in conflict environments, and a former Senior Advisor in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Don Eberly has held senior civilian positions on the front lines of the two major wars of the 21st Century. He recently completed a sixteen month tour at the Command Headquarters in Kandahar, Afghanistan serving as Director of Regional Strategy, overseeing the effort to build governing institutions. For his service in Iraq and Afghanistan he has earned the most prestigious meritorious service awards.

Eberly has served as a White House aid under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, and has advised numerous other national figures. He is a nationally recognized author who has published numerous books, including an award winning book detailing the rise worldwide of civic and enterprise solutions, which has been adopted by the State Department books program. He also wrote a book detailing U.S. operations in the immediate post-war period in Iraq where he was a Senior Advisor, taking over the functions of Saddam Hussein's son Uday. He was the first American civilian into Baghdad city hall after the fall of Baghdad, where he was sent to restore services.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: La Jetee
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: La Jetee

fulldesc.p: Description: Humanities Film Series presents a screening of La Jetee as well as a special screening of Denied Authenticity, an installation by Dr. Ben Cunningham.
Plot Summary:

La Jetee- Chris Marker's short film La Jetée has haunted audiences for decades with its story of a WWIII survivor sent back in time to find a way to aid the post-apocalyptic world he inhabits. Marker uniquely unfolds the story using stills with narration, a structure that ignites questions about the nature of memory and time.

Denied Authenticity - In the video presentation of his installation, “Denied Authenticity,” Ben Cunningham presents the impersonal and detached relationship between America and its involvement in Iraq and Afghanistan through a simple yet profound mix of print and visual media. Distance and nearness are juxtaposed with names and faces. Ben’s condenses the complex issue of war down to a human, individual question. Viewers of “Denied Authenticity” will be compelled to come to terms with their perspectives of America’s foreign conflicts
Discussant: Dr. Caleb Corkery, Dr. Greg Seigworth, Dr. Jill Craven, and Dr. Ben Cunningham
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences
“I believe in the power of art to generate social change. Through it, I strive to empower by giving a voice to those without.” –Ben Cunningham

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Dr. Richard Carmona, former U.S. Surgeon General Public Lecture
event.shortdesc: Only in America: From High School Drop out to Surgeon General

fulldesc.p: Description: "Only in America: From High School Drop Out to Surgeon General."

Bio: In 2002, Dr. Richard Carmona, the 17th Surgeon General of the United States, was selected because of his extensive experience in public health, clinical sciences, health care management, preparedness and his commitment to prevention as an effective means to improve public health and reduce health care costs, while improving the quality and quantity of life. At the University of California Medical School, Carmona was awarded the prestigious gold-headed cane as the top graduate. Trained in general and vascular surgery, Carmona also completed a National Institutes of Health-sponsored fellowship in trauma, burns and critical care and was then recruited jointly by the Tucson Medical Center and the University of Arizona to start and direct Arizona's first regional trauma care system. He then became chairman of the State of Arizona Southern Regional Emergency Medical System, a professor of surgery, public health and family and community medicine at the University of Arizona, and the Pima County Sheriff's Department surgeon and deputy sheriff.

He is also a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, President of the nonprofit Canyon Ranch Institute and the first Distinguished Professor of Public Health at the University of Arizona's Mel and Enid Zuckerman College of Public Health. Recently, DCarmona partnered with Lance Armstrong and the three other former U.S. Surgeon Generals to launch the first National Call to Action on Cancer Prevention and Survivorship.
Sponsors: Society on Latino Affairs, Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, University Theme Committee, Lancaster Partnership Programs, Nursing Department, Latino/a Studies.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Artist Exhibit: Karabakh on my Mind
event.shortdesc: The art exhibit, "Karabakh on my Mind" featuring Azerbaijani artist, Yavar Rzayev, will be held at Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince Street.

fulldesc.p: Description: The art exhibit, "Karabakh on my Mind" featuring Azerbaijani artist Yavar Rzayev, will be held at Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince Street beginning April 1. His exhibit is a collection of paintings of the countryside of the town in which he grew up.

Rzayev's work will be featured in the Gallery beginning First Friday, April 1. His work will be featured on specially built movable walls, debuting that night, located in an area visible from Prince Street. The artist will be in attendance from 6-8 p.m. There will also be music in the lobby, following an 8 p.m. performance by the Millersville University Orchestra in Steinman Hall.
After April 1, the exhibit will take up residence for the remainder of the month in the Gallery space.

Biography: Yavar Rzayev is a multi-faceted architect, designer, artist and performer. His artistic works include monochrome drawings; mixed media contemporary paintings; watercolor; illustrations; oil on canvas or wood panels; and live model portraiture. Yavar was born in 1962 in Azerbaijan. His art pieces have appeared in several international art festivals, solo and group shows and are located in private collections in Azerbaijan; Germany; Czechoslovakia; Mexico; Palm Springs,California; Fort Lauderdale, Florida; Washington, DC; Rehoboth Beach, Delaware and New York.

link.name: Watch a video of an interview with Rzayev, taken opening night of his show in D.C.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Monty Python and the Holy Grail
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Monty Python and the Holy Grail

fulldesc.p: Directed by Terry Gilliam and Terry Jones, Monty Python and the Holy Grail was the first of the Python team's legendary comedy films and the source of Broadway's Spamalot. A cult classic, The Holy Grail explores the quest of King Arthur and his "silly English k-nig-hts" to locate the grail in a land where peasants question their socioeconomic status, French soldiers catapult cows, people ponder the airspeed velocity of swallows, knights demand shrubberies, and a killer bunny runs amok. Best appreciated with a crowd, this offbeat satire of Arthurian legend launched some of film's silliest quoted lines. "Now go away or I shall taunt you a second time."
Discussant: Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

After the cash-strapped dad takes a job moonlighting for a drug company, however, Jack's suspicions about his favorite male nurse come roaring back. event.title: Humanities Film Series: Run Lola Run
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Run Lola Run

fulldesc.p: Winner of the Audience Award at Sundance and Best Film, Best Director, and Best Actress at the German Film Awards, Tom Twyker's critically acclaimed Lola rennt chronicles three alternative adventures for Lola as she tries to raise 100,000 Deutsche Marks in 20 minutes to save her boyfriend Manni from imminent harm. Small decisions that Lola makes alter her possible futures as she strives to complete her task on time. This film illustrates how small decisions have the potential to make large impacts ("the Butterfly Effect") on potential futures. In German with English subtitles.
Discussant: Dr. Chuck Ward, Associate Professor of Philosophy, and members of the Ciné Club and the Philosophy Club at Millersville University

event.title: Peace-Education-Ireland Symposium/Kenderdine Lecture with Caitlin Donnelly
event.shortdesc: Dr. Caitlin Donnelly will present the Peace-Education-Ireland Symposium/Kenderdine Lecture

fulldesc.p:
Description: Dr. Caitlin Donnelly, School of Education, Queen’s University Belfast Northern Ireland will present the Peace-Education-Ireland Symposium/Kenderdine Lecture, April 6 at 7 p.m. This event is free and open to the public and will be held in the multipurpose room of Stayer Hall.
Title: Church Involvement in Education-Lessons from Northern Ireland

Biography: Donnelly was appointed as lecturer in the School of Education, Queen's University in September 2005. Her main research interests and areas of expertise are schools and inter-group relations, school ethos and the role of education in plural and divided societies. She has undertaken research and published widely on these themes.

Donnelly is a member of the research cluster 'Education in Divided societies' within the School of Education and has undertaken a range of research projects related to this subject. Her current research projects include an examination of inter-school collaboration in Northern Ireland; an exploration of parental attitudes in integrated schools in Northern Ireland and bi-national/bi-lingual schools in Israel and Social identity within Catholic and Protestant schools in Northern Ireland.

event.title: Holocaust Conference Concert
event.shortdesc: A concert featuring works by Jewish composers, with Anita Renfroe and Ioannis Potamousis, duo pianists and Matti Kovler, composer.

fulldesc.p: Description: A concert featuring works by Jewish composers will be held April 6, at 7 p.m. at Millersville University - Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. Dr. Anita Renfroe and Ioannis Potamousis, duo pianists and Matti Kovler, composer, will perform this concert, which is being held in conjunction with the 31st Annual Conference on the Holocaust & Genocide, held April 7-8 at Millersville University.
Grand Tarantelle - duo - Louis Moreau Gottschalk (1829-1869)
Variations on a Shaker Melody - duet - Aaron Copland (1900-1990)
Carmen Fantasy - duo - Abrhan Chasins (1903-1987)
Yiddish Dances - duet - Adam Gorb (1958-)
Intermission

Jewishness in Music - a Personal Take - Russian-born Israel composer Kovler talks about the Jewish element in his music, from a 21st Century composer-immigrant's perspective, presenting some of his works.

p.strong: This performance is free and open to the public; however, tickets are required. Tickets may be picked up

event.title: 31st Annual Conference on the Holocaust & Genocide
event.shortdesc: 31st Annual Conference on the Holocaust and Genocide

fulldesc.p: Description: The 31st Annual Conference on the Holocaust will be held April 7-8 at Millersville University. This year's conference will focus on memories of the Holocaust and Genocide, provided by survivors, witnesses and perpetrators in different countries and at different times. Memories of the Holocaust and Genocide, their importance for the reconstruction and examination of the historical past as well as commemoration of the Holocaust and Genocide in various countries will be discussed at the conference.

Registration of invited conference participants begins at 9:30 a.m., Thursday, April 7. Sessions will run from 10 a.m.-5:45 p.m., followed by the keynote speech at 7:15 p.m. by Trinity College Professor Samuel Kassow, "History as Cultural Resistance: Emanuel Ringelblum and his Archive."
The Holocaust and Genocide Conference will continue on Friday, April 8, from 9 a.m.-12:45 p.m.

p.strong: All conference events are free and open to the public.

fulldesc.p: For more information on the 31st Annual Conference on the Holocaust and Genocide, contact Victoria Khiterer, this year's conference director, at 717-871-5525 or Victoria.Khiterer@millersville.edu.
For the full conference schedule, visit the Holocaust and Genocide conference website, www.millersville.edu/holocon/.

event.title: Ville After Dark Speaker: Dana Gilmore
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Speaker - Dana Gilmore

fulldesc.p: Dana Gilmore's brand of poetry is both invigorating and cathartic. She has appeared on seasons 3 and 4 of HBO's Def Poetry Jam where she received several standing ovations. She also has shared the stage with artists such as Mos Def, Kanye West, Anthony Hamilton and the legendary Smokey Robinson. Gilmore's poetic style is very clear-cut and real. For her, all of life can be interpreted through her poetry. She presents them in a form that is rare, yet real. Dana speaks passionately, yet practically, about life's adversities, as well as alternatives for dealing with those realities. Some call writing a gift, for Dana, It's a calling.

event.title: The Dilemma
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie - The Dilemma

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary - A man finds out that what you don't say to a friend is just as important as what you do is this story of how far you can bend a brotherly bond before it snaps. Since college, confirmed bachelor Ronny (Vaughn) and happily married Nick (James) have been through thick and thin. Now partners in an auto design firm, the two pals are vying to land a dream project that would launch their company. Ronny's girlfriend, Beth (Connelly), and Nick's wife, Geneva (Ryder), are by their sides. But Ronny's world is turned upside down when he inadvertently sees Geneva out with another man and makes it his mission to get answers. As the amateur investigation dissolves into mayhem, he learns that Nick has a few secrets of his own. Now, with the clock ticking and pressure mounting on the biggest presentation of their careers, Ronny must decide what will happen if he reveals the truth to his best friend.
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: End The Violence
event.shortdesc: Join us for a screening of the film "Power and Control: Domestic Violence in America" by Peter Cohn. event.title: Lecture: Hill Harper
event.shortdesc: Hill Harper, an actor on the hit drama series CSI: New York, will speak at Millersville.

fulldesc.p: Description: Hill Harper, Esq., "Motivating Young Men to be the Architect of Their Life."

Biography: Harper has won legions of admirers for his soulful portrayal of "Dr. Sheldon Hawkes" on the hit drama series CSI: New York. A talented actor, Harper's passion for his craft is surpassed only by his dedication to inspire America's youth. A firm believer that identity is not defined by skin color or circumstance, the charismatic Harper encourages audiences to "take your biggest dream, and double it."

Harper's newest book, The Conversation, explores the nature of love across generations and the current state of male-female relations. It offers practical solutions on how to improve communication across gender and age.

Wanting to make a mark past his writing, Harper works to enable positive social change as a spokesman and volunteer for Big Brothers, Big Sisters. Today, he continues in his efforts to better America's social climate and guide our youth as a strong and articulate voice for hope, education, and commitment.
Sponsors: Dr. Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, Federick Douglass Celebration of Black Culture.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: The Search for Birth Parents in China
event.shortdesc: Dr. Changfu Chang presents his documentaries, "Sofia's Journey" and "Daughters' Return"

fulldesc.p: Millersville University will be presenting Dr. Changfu Chang's "The Search for Birth Parents in China," a screening of two documentaries, "Sofia's Journey" and "Daughters' Return," in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall, on Wednesday, April 13 from 7-9:30 p.m.

"Sofia's Journey" and"Daughters' Return" show the journeys of three teenagers as they search China to find their birth parents. Each one ends up searching for their own past, identity and place in relationships intertwined with abandonment and love.

More than 100,000 children have been adopted out of China in thelast two decades. Chinese birth parents are "invisible," for cultural and political reasons, resulting in adopted children not knowing their own roots. This lack of information for adoptees coming of age creates a sense of disappointment, frustration, loss and can lead to identity crises.

The documentaries were directed and produced by Dr.Changfu Chang, professor of communication and theatre, in collaboration with Millersville University faculty and students from departments including communication and theatre, English, music, art and sociology.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Parallax View
event.shortdesc: Reframing Conspiracy

fulldesc.p:
From the director of "All the President's Men" and the cinematographer of "The Godfather," Alan J. Pakula's The Parallax View emerged as one of the major political conspiracy thrillers of the 1970s.
In the film, reporter Joe Frady (Warren Beatty) investigates a potential conspiracy revolving around the assassination of a Senator and involving the enigmatic Parallax Corporation.
Discussant: Dr. Greg Seigworth, Professor of Communications and Theater
Sponsor: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

event.title: Teach For America
event.shortdesc: Phi Sigma Pi is raising awareness of educational inequity and promoting Teach For America by hosting a speaker and showing the movie, The Lottery.

fulldesc.p:
Educational inequity prevents children from fulfilling their potential. It limits life choices, professional options, and incomes, and weakens families and communities. Because children in low-income communities are predominantly children of color, they also face the added burden of societal low expectations and discrimination.
That's where Teach For America comes in!
Teach For America provides a critical source of well-trained t-eachers who are helping break the cycle of educational inequity. These teachers, called corps members, commit to teach for two years in one of 39 urban and rural regions across the country, going above and beyond traditional expectations to help their students to achieve at high levels.
Rachel Martin, a recent graduate of Millersville University, is one of these teachers. Rachel will be here to speak about her experiences with TFA as well as TFA as a whole.
After Rachel's talk, the 2010 film The Lottery will be shown. The Lottery uncovers the failures of the traditional public school system and reveals that hundreds of thousands of parents attempt to flee the system every year. The Lottery follows four of these families from Harlem and the Bronx who have entered their children in a charter school lottery. Out of thousands of hopefuls, only a small minority will win the chance of a better future.
Refreshments will be served!

event.title: Ville After Dark: The Hangover
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie: The Hangover

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: Angelenos Doug Billings and Tracy Garner are about to get married. Two days before the wedding, the four men in the wedding party - Doug, Doug's two best buddies Phil Wenneck and Stu Price, and Tracy's brother Alan Garner - hop into Tracy's father's beloved Mercedes convertible for a 24-hour stag party to Las Vegas. Phil, a married high school teacher, has the same maturity level as his students when he's with his pals. Stu, a dentist, is worried about everything, especially what his controlling girlfriend Melissa thinks. Because she disapproves of traditional male bonding rituals, Stu has to lie to her about the stag, he telling her that they are going on a wine tasting tour in the Napa Valley. Regardless, he intends on eventually marrying her, against the advice and wishes of his friends. And Alan seems to be unaware of what are considered the social graces of the western world. The morning after their arrival in Las Vegas, they awaken in their hotel suite each with the worst hangover. None remembers what happened in the past twelve or so hours. The suite is in shambles. And certain things are in the suite that shouldn't be, and certain things that should be in the suite are missing. Probably the most important in the latter category is Doug. As Phil, Stu and Alan try to find Doug using only what little pieces of information they have at hand, they go on a journey of discovery of how certain things got into the suite and what happened to the missing items. However they are on a race for time as if they can't find Doug in the next few hours, they are going to have to explain to Tracy why they are not yet back in Los Angeles. And even worse, they may not find Doug at all before the wedding.

p.em: This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Ville After Dark: No Strings Attached
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie - No Strings Attached

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: Lifelong friends Adam (Ashton Kutcher) and Emma (Natalie Portman) attempt to avoid falling in love after falling into each other's beds in this comedy exploring the complexities and quirks of having friends with benefits. Adam was a typical, hormonal 14 year old when he first came on to Emma at summer camp -- and got shot down in flames. In the years that followed, however, Adam and Emma continued to cross paths until eventually, they both caved to their animal instincts. Despite an intense session of earth-shaking sex, however, Emma makes it clear to Adam that the last thing she wants is a committed relationship. And thanks to the fact that Adam's father (Kevin Kline), a fallen television star, has just begun dating his son's ex-girlfriend, the horrified bachelor has developed an aversion to monogamy as well. At first their casual stance on sex works great for both; Emma can focus on her career instead of allowing her emotions to dictate her decisions, and Adam can play the field without fear of hurting her feelings. Over, time, however, a funny thing happens -- Adam began to develop feelings for Emma that he never had for any of his countless conquests. Before they both know it, love has reared its ugly head and they've gotten too emotionally involved to cut the relationship off cold. But is commitment in the cards for the couple that always swore it would never get serious, or has the time come for them to finally part ways once and for all?
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Memento
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Memento

fulldesc.p:
Description: Christopher Nolan's Memento tells the story of bereaved husband Leonard, who is deprived of his memory and lives his snippets of life to avenge his murdered wife. The scenes of the main storyline unfold backwards, keeping spectators curious about how time and memory interrelate. Spectators learn that Leonard actively remixes his present to his own emotional advantage.
Like "Mr. Nobody," the film's creative structure engages spectators to create the film, exercising their imaginations with the potential structures the film's story could take.
Discussant: Dr. Lowery Woodall, Assistant Professor of Communications and Theater
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public. No tickets required.

event.title: Jeff Johnson: A Public Lecture
event.shortdesc: Jeff Johnson is a Washington, D.C. based award-winning journalist, social activist and political commentator.

fulldesc.p: Description: Jeff Johnson, a Washington, D.C. based award-winning journalist, social activist and political commentator will be speaking at Millersville University, April 20, at 7:30 p.m. This event will take place on campus in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

Biography: From his celebrated conversations with marquee world figures in the political, business and entertainment arenas to his grass-roots trench work to inspire the next generation of leaders; investigative journalist, political correspondent and activist, Johnson continues to be a trailblazing social entrepreneur and authentic voice for change.

Johnson spent the last decade merging the worlds of politics and popular culture including his work as Senior Advisor for Media and Youth Outreach for People for the American Way, National Director of the Youth & College division of the NAACP and an appointment by Russell Simmons as the Vice President of the Hip Hop Summit Action Network (HSAN).
Johnson consistently challenges audiences to innovatively weigh solutions to resolve historic and systemic social imbalances and inequalities.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public. No tickets required.

event.title: Guest Artist Sonia Lee, Harpsichord
event.shortdesc: Millersville's music department presents guest artist Sonia Lee, harpsichord.

fulldesc.p: Description: As part of the spring 2011 piano symposium, the Department of Music at Millersville University welcomes Sonia Lee, harpsichord, as a guest artist, April 26. Lee will be on campus, in the Form Atrium of McComsey Hall from 2:30-3:30 p.m. for workshops with music classes, followed by a recital at 7 p.m.
This program features harpsichord music of the French clavecinistes and the North German school, as well as a work for flute or harpsichord by J.S. Bach.

Artist Bio: As an award-winning early keyboardist, Lee, has been praised by critics for her "very high standard of playing" and her ability "to dazzle an enraptured audience." She has been heard as soloist at festivals as well as regional and international conferences.

As a continuo player on both harpsichord and organ, she has collaborated with numerous soloists and ensembles. An advocate of contemporary harpsichord music, she has performed works by such prize-winning composers as Dagmar Feyen, James Dorsa, Asako Hirabayashi, and Luis Mucillo. The recipient of numerous awards and grants, Lee is a laureate of the Montreal Baroque Galaxie-CBC Rising Star Competition, the Mae and Irving Jurow International Harpsichord Competition, the Canadian Music Competitions and the William E. Gribbons Award sponsored by the American Musical Instrument Society.
Currently, she is on the adjunct music history faculty at Illinois Wesleyan University.
